definitions.definition: To get into one's hands, possession , or control , with or without force .
examples: They took Charlton's gun from his cold, dead hands.
I'll take that plate off the table.

subdefinitions.definition: To seize or capture .
examples: After a bloody battle, they were able to take the city.

subdefinitions.definition: To catch or get possession of (fish or game).
examples: took ten catfish in one afternoon

subdefinitions.definition: To catch the ball; especially as a wicket-keeper and after the batsman has missed or edged it.
To appropriate or transfer into one's own possession, sometimes by physically carrying off.
examples: Billy took her pencil.

subdefinitions.definition: To exact .
To capture or win (a piece or trick ) in a game .
examples: took the next two tricks
took Smith's rook

definitions.definition: To receive or accept (something, especially something which was given ).
examples: took third place
took bribes
The camera takes 35mm film.

subdefinitions.definition: To receive or accept (something) as payment or compensation .
examples: The store doesn't take checks.
She wouldn't take any money for her help.
Do you take plastic?
The vending machine only takes bills, it doesn't take coins.

subdefinitions.definition: To accept and follow (advice , etc.).
examples: take my advice

subdefinitions.definition: To receive into some relationship.
examples: The school only takes new students in the fall.
The therapist wouldn't take him as a client.

subdefinitions.definition: To receive or acquire (property) by law (e.g. as an heir).
To accept , be given (rightly or wrongly), or assume (especially as if by right ).
examples: He took all the credit for the project, although he had done almost none of the work.
She took the blame, in the public's eyes, although the debacle was more her husband's fault than her own.

definitions.definition: To remove .
examples: take two eggs from the carton

subdefinitions.definition: To remove or end by death ; to kill .
examples: The earthquake took many lives.
The plague took rich and poor alike.
Cancer took her life.
He took his life last night.

subdefinitions.definition: To subtract .
examples: Take one from three and you are left with two.

definitions.definition: To have sex with.
To defeat (someone or something) in a fight .
examples: Don't try to take that guy. He's bigger than you.
The woman guarding us looks like a professional, but I can take her!

definitions.definition: To grasp or grip .
examples: He took her hand in his.

definitions.definition: To select or choose ; to pick .
examples: Take whichever bag you like.
She took the best men with her and left the rest to garrison the city.
I'll take the blue plates.
I'll take two sugars in my coffee, please.

subdefinitions.definition: To adopt ( select ) as one's own.
examples: She took his side in every argument.

definitions.definition: To carry or lead (something or someone).
examples: She took her sword with her everywhere she went.
I'll take the plate with me.

subdefinitions.definition: To transport or carry ; to convey to another place.
examples: The next bus will take you to Metz.
I took him for a ride
I took him down to London.

subdefinitions.definition: To lead (to a place); to serve as a means of reaching.
examples: These stairs take you down to the basement.
Stone Street took us right past the store.
subdefinitions.label_groups: transitive , of a path, road , etc.

subdefinitions.definition: To pass (or attempt to pass) through or around.
examples: She took the steps two or three at a time.
He took the curve / corner too fast.
The pony took every hedge and fence in its path.

subdefinitions.definition: To escort or conduct (a person).
examples: He took her to lunch at the new restaurant, took her to the movies, and then took her home.

subdefinitions.definition: To go .

definitions.definition: To use as a means of transportation .
examples: take the ferry
I took a plane.
He took the bus to London, and then took a train to Manchester.
He's 96 but he still takes the stairs.

definitions.definition: To obtain for use by payment or lease .
examples: She took a condo at the beach for the summer.
He took a full-page ad in the Times .
Times

subdefinitions.definition: To obtain or receive regularly by (paid) subscription .
examples: They took two magazines.
I used to take The Sunday Times .
The Sunday Times

definitions.definition: To receive ( medicine or drugs ) into one's body , e.g. by inhalation or swallowing ; to ingest .
examples: take two of these and call me in the morning
take the blue pill
I take aspirin every day to thin my blood.

definitions.definition: To consume (food or drink).
examples: The general took dinner at seven o'clock.

definitions.definition: To undergo ; to put oneself into, to be subjected to.
examples: She made the decision to take chemotherapy.

definitions.definition: To experience or feel .
examples: She takes pride in her work.
I take offence at that.

definitions.definition: To submit to; to endure (without ill humor , resentment , or physical failure ).
examples: took a pay cut
If you're in an abusive relationship, don't just sit and take it; you can get help.
The hull took a lot of punishment before it broke.
I can take the noise, but I can't take the smell.
That truck bed will only take two tons.

definitions.definition: To suffer ; to endure (a hardship or damage ).
examples: The ship took a direct hit and was destroyed.
Her career took a hit.

definitions.definition: To participate in.
examples: She took a vacation to France but spent the whole time feeling miserable that her husband couldn't be there with her.
Aren't you supposed to take your math final today?
Despite my misgivings, I decided to take a meeting with the Russian lawyer.

definitions.definition: To cause to change to a specified state or condition .
examples: He had to take it apart to fix it.
She took down her opponent in two minutes.

definitions.definition: To regard in a specified way.
examples: He took the news badly.

definitions.definition: To conclude or form (a decision or an opinion) in the mind.
examples: took the decision to close its last remaining outlet
took a dim view of city officials

definitions.definition: To understand (especially in a specified way).
examples: Don't take my comments as an insult.
if she took my meaning

definitions.definition: To believe , to accept the statements of.
examples: take her word for it
take him at his word

definitions.definition: To assume or suppose ; to reckon ; to regard or consider .
examples: I took him to be a person of honor.
He was often taken to be a man of means.
Do you take me for a fool?
Do you take me to be stupid?
Looking at him as he came into the room, I took him for his father.

definitions.definition: To draw , derive , or deduce (a meaning from something).
examples: take it from her comments she won't be there.
I'm not sure what moral to take from that story.

definitions.definition: To derive (as a title); to obtain from a source .
examples: "As I Lay Dying" takes its title from Book XI of Homer's "Odyssey"

definitions.definition: To catch or contract (an illness , etc.).
examples: took a chill
to take cold

definitions.definition: To come upon or catch (in a particular state or situation).
To captivate or charm ; to gain or secure the interest or affection of.
examples: took her fancy
took her attention

definitions.definition: To absorb or be impregnated by (dye, ink , etc.); to be susceptible to being treated by (polish , etc.).
examples: cloth that takes dye well
The flu shot didn't take (on me).
the leather that takes a certain kind of polish

definitions.definition: To let in (water).
To require ( a person, resource or thing in order to achieve an outcome ) .
examples: Looks like it's gonna take a taller person to get that down.
Finishing this on schedule will take a lot of overtime.

definitions.definition: To proceed to fill.
examples: He took a seat in the front row.

definitions.definition: To fill , occupy , require, or use up (space).
examples: His collection takes a lot of space.

definitions.definition: To fill or require: to last or expend (an amount of time).
examples: Unloading the moving truck took us half a day, but this mess of a house will take us all weekend to tidy up. It takes ages to finish house moving!
Hunting that whale takes most of his free time.
The trip will take about ten minutes.
It takes a while to get used to the smell.

definitions.definition: To avail oneself of; to exploit .
examples: He took that opportunity to leave France.

definitions.definition: To practice ; perform ; execute ; carry out ; do .
examples: take a walk
take action/steps/measures to fight drug abuse
take a trip
take aim
take the tempo slowly
The kick is taken from where the foul occurred.
Pirès ran in to take the kick.
The throw-in is taken from the point where the ball crossed the touch-line.

definitions.definition: To assume or perform (a form or role).

subdefinitions.definition: To assume (a form).
examples: took the form of a duck
took shape
a god taking the likeness of a bird

subdefinitions.definition: To perform (a role).
examples: take the part of the villain/hero

subdefinitions.definition: To assume and undertake the duties of (a job, an office , etc.).
examples: take office
take the throne

definitions.definition: To bind oneself by.
examples: he took the oath of office last night

definitions.definition: To go into, through, or along.
examples: go down two blocks and take the next left
take the path of least resistance

subdefinitions.definition: To go or move into.
examples: the witness took the stand
the next team took the field

definitions.definition: To have and use one's recourse to.
To ascertain or determine by measurement , examination or inquiry .
To write down; to get in, or as if in, writing.
examples: He took a mental inventory of his supplies.
She took careful notes.

definitions.definition: To make (a photograph, film, or other reproduction of something).
examples: She took a video of their encounter.
Could you take a picture of us?

definitions.definition: To make a picture, photograph , etc. of (a person, scene , etc.).
examples: The photographer will take you sitting down.
to take a group/scene

definitions.definition: To obtain money from, especially by swindling .
examples: took me for ten grand

definitions.definition: To apply oneself to the study of.
examples: As a child, she took ballet.
Next semester, I plan to take math, physics, literature, and art history.
labels: now chiefly by enrolling in a class or course
definitions.label_groups: transitive , now chiefly by enrolling in a class or course

definitions.definition: To deal with.
examples: take matters as they arise

definitions.definition: To consider in a particular way, or to consider as an example.
examples: I've had a lot of problems recently: take last Monday, for example. My car broke down on the way to work. Then [ … ] etc.

definitions.definition: To decline to swing at (a pitched ball); to refrain from hitting at, and allow to pass.
examples: He'll probably take this one.

definitions.definition: To accept as an input to a relation.

subdefinitions.definition: To have to be used with (a certain grammatical form , etc.).
examples: This verb takes the dative; that verb takes the genitive.

subdefinitions.definition: To accept (zero or more arguments ).
examples: The function takes two arguments, an array of size n and an integer k .
n
k

definitions.definition: To buy .
examples: take a ticket

definitions.definition: To get or accept (something) into one's possession .
examples: My husband and I have a dysfunctional marriage. He just takes and takes ; he never gives.

definitions.definition: To engage, take hold or have effect.

subdefinitions.definition: To adhere or be absorbed properly.
examples: the dye didn't take
Boiling pasta with a bit of the sauce in the water will help the sauce " take ."

subdefinitions.definition: To begin to grow after being grafted or planted; to ( literally or figuratively ) take root , take hold.
examples: not all grafts take
I started some tomato seeds last spring, but they didn't take .

subdefinitions.definition: To catch; to engage.
To win acceptance, favor or favorable reception; to charm people.

definitions.definition: To become; to be affected in a specified way.
examples: They took ill within 3 hours.
She took sick with the flu.

definitions.definition: To be able to be accurately or beautifully photographed.
An intensifier.
To deliver , bring , give (something) to (someone).
To give or deliver (a blow, to someone); to strike or hit.
examples: He took me a blow on the head.
definitions.label_groups: transitive , obsolete outside dialects and slang

definitions.definition: To visit ; to include in a course of travel.
To portray in a painting .
Used in phrasal verbs: take in , take off , take on , take out , take to , take something to , take up .

main_definition: ( transitive ) To get into one's hands, possession , or control , with or without force .
secondary_definitions: ( transitive ) To receive or accept (something, especially something which was given ).
( transitive ) To remove .
( transitive ) To have sex with.
( transitive ) To defeat (someone or something) in a fight .
( transitive ) To grasp or grip .
( transitive ) To select or choose ; to pick .
( transitive ) To carry or lead (something or someone).
( transitive ) To use as a means of transportation .
( transitive ) To obtain for use by payment or lease .
( transitive ) To receive ( medicine or drugs ) into one's body , e.g. by inhalation or swallowing ; to ingest .
( transitive ) To consume (food or drink).
( transitive ) To undergo ; to put oneself into, to be subjected to.
( transitive ) To experience or feel .
( transitive ) To submit to; to endure (without ill humor , resentment , or physical failure ).
( transitive ) To suffer ; to endure (a hardship or damage ).
( transitive ) To participate in.
( transitive ) To cause to change to a specified state or condition .
( transitive ) To regard in a specified way.
( transitive ) To conclude or form (a decision or an opinion) in the mind.
( transitive ) To understand (especially in a specified way).
( transitive ) To believe , to accept the statements of.
( transitive ) To assume or suppose ; to reckon ; to regard or consider .
( transitive ) To draw , derive , or deduce (a meaning from something).
( transitive ) To derive (as a title); to obtain from a source .
( transitive ) To catch or contract (an illness , etc.).
( transitive ) To come upon or catch (in a particular state or situation).
( transitive ) To captivate or charm ; to gain or secure the interest or affection of.
( transitive , of a material ) To absorb or be impregnated by (dye, ink , etc.); to be susceptible to being treated by (polish , etc.).
( transitive , of a ship ) To let in (water).
( transitive ) To require ( a person, resource or thing in order to achieve an outcome ) .
( transitive ) To proceed to fill.
( transitive ) To fill , occupy , require, or use up (space).
( transitive ) To fill or require: to last or expend (an amount of time).
( transitive ) To avail oneself of; to exploit .
( transitive ) To practice ; perform ; execute ; carry out ; do .
( transitive ) To assume or perform (a form or role).
( transitive ) To bind oneself by.
( transitive ) To go into, through, or along.
( transitive ) To have and use one's recourse to.
( transitive ) To ascertain or determine by measurement , examination or inquiry .
( transitive ) To write down; to get in, or as if in, writing.
( transitive ) To make (a photograph, film, or other reproduction of something).
( transitive , dated ) To make a picture, photograph , etc. of (a person, scene , etc.).
( transitive ) To obtain money from, especially by swindling .
( transitive , now chiefly by enrolling in a class or course ) To apply oneself to the study of.
( transitive ) To deal with.
( transitive ) To consider in a particular way, or to consider as an example.
( transitive , baseball ) To decline to swing at (a pitched ball); to refrain from hitting at, and allow to pass.
( transitive ) To accept as an input to a relation.
( transitive , Greece , Cyprus , informal ) To buy .
( intransitive ) To get or accept (something) into one's possession .
( intransitive ) To engage, take hold or have effect.
( intransitive , copulative ) To become; to be affected in a specified way.
( intransitive , possibly dated ) To be able to be accurately or beautifully photographed.
( intransitive , dialectal , proscribed ) An intensifier.
( transitive , obsolete ) To deliver , bring , give (something) to (someone).
( transitive , obsolete outside dialects and slang ) To give or deliver (a blow, to someone); to strike or hit.
( archaic ) To visit ; to include in a course of travel.
( obsolete , rare ) To portray in a painting .
Used in phrasal verbs: take in , take off , take on , take out , take to , take something to , take up .
